utterances: So, one on one.
Who do you like in a one on one between those two in a town hall?
To whose benefit is this?
Well, of course, John McCain is hoping it's to his.
He's done pretty well in those kind of - you know, his Straight Talk Expresses.
I think he does well in that form, but I think Barack does well on that, too.
Yes, I am.
They both - I mean, he shows his charisma.
I actually went to an Obama rally to see what the fuss was about, about a year and a half ago, which seems like a lifetime ago, and I got it.
You know, and McCain, I hear, plays well in that setting, too.
So, it will be very interesting.
Yeah, I think, you know, for Obama to do well in a situation like that, he has to basically just be himself.
And, you know, what McCain's going to try and do, to my way of thinking, is he'll try to say, well, look, but you don't have the experience to do the kind of stuff that I've done.
And Obama's response of course will be, well, yeah, but you're not change.
You're the same old stuff.
And in this town-hall setting, it depends on who the people in the crowd are and what kind of reaction you're going to get.
If, you know, if the Republicans can get a lot of their people in there to support McCain, then of course, it'll seem like McCain went to all of the debates.
And we're talking about having an independent commission, you know, stack - you know, bring the people in.
I'm always suspicious of that because, you know, some parties have been very, very good at stacking the deck in their favor depending on where you are.
Are you surprised, either of you, Erin or Bob, that the polls show currently that McCain and Obama are in a virtual dead heat?
No, I'm not surprised.
I - again, you know, this is completely unscripted, unprecedented.
I never know where Obama's going to land, you know, so I'd say for this - it's like right now, everybody's - both - they both got an A in class, and it's theirs to lose.
Right.
Yeah.
And there's no question.
McCain has a lot of the support of the old die hards, the old, the GOP.
Even conservative Democrats who would like to support him.
But Obama has the young people, who have come out in tremendous numbers to support him.
So, a dead heat right now, I don't think is a surprise.

What's going to end up being - making the difference, I think, are the debates and are - as we get down the - through the order of the campaign, and you know, we haven't seen, you know the robe of vocation of Obama yet, you know?
(Soundbite of laughter)
And we know that's going to be coming, although, you know, I don't know how much dirt they can dig up on Obama.
I mean, I'm sure there's some things, but it seems to me like he's a pretty clean-cut guy and there may not be much to dig up on.
But you know, I have to say one thing.
Go ahead.

And that is this gets to the conversation you had earlier about this whole - you know, Obama's nomination, that is whatever - even if there's no dirt to dig up on, I mean, this is a question of national identity.
People vote president - they vote in a presidential election, they're voting for a guy who will represent them.
And the idea of a black man representing all of us, is a really radical one.
And in that - and that's what'll - that is wha - really what we're voting on.
That we've never voted on before.
And a scary one.
And a scary...
To a lot of people.
Yes.
Absolutely.
We're going to have Beth Fouhy call me back in just a second.
So, before I say goodbye to you, do you think that the campaign going fourth will be gentlemanly, if I can use that word, or will it be nasty between Obama and McCain?
I think on Obama's part, you know, I - he's been a very - a gentleman so far, and I don't know that he'll change that.
I don't think that McCain is - he has been a gentleman too.
But you know, in politics, you don't - the candidate doesn't control the message anymore.
So, I think the kernel is going to get nasty, and it may not be because McCain wants it to, or Obama wants it to.

But because their supporters - their packs will put these ads on the air, you know, I mean, we're going to be hearing about Barack, we're seeing Obama an awful lot over the next couple of months, and it won't be because McCain wants it to happen.
All right.
Let me ask you both to just sit tight for a minute.
Beth, are you out there?
I sure am.
All right, let's bring you back in.
We were - when we last talked to you, you were going to tell us what happened at Dianne Feinstein's house last night, when Obama and Hillary Clinton got together.
The wire say that she left him downstairs on a sofa with a bottle of water, and she went upstairs to do her work, and she didn't see them again until it was all over.
So, what did they do?
Beth?
Oh, we lost her again.
OK, well, cell phone.
We're going to - maybe when Obama or McCain become president, they can fix the cell-phone problems that we have.
(Soundbite of laughter)
When we -we - that's why I asked you guys to stick around just in case.
OK.
So, we were talking about the fact that it may be, that the candidate doesn't control the message...
That's what they say.
All the time.
Well, you don't buy that?
Well, McCain had said this before.
I mean and he - one positive think McCain who has slimed himself back in 2004 by, you know, racially by the way, has pledged, I will not - I'm not bringing that dirt into the campaign.
But he has said - I think it was over an ad that aired not that long ago.
I don't remember the ad, but he said, I don't like that ad, but hey, I don't have - I can't control the message.
I think sometimes that's true, sometimes it's just ingenuousness.

Let me ask you another question, because it seems to me that this time around, more so than in '04, or in 2000, or going back even before then, that the presidential - the vice-presidential candidate is really going to be important.
Do you share that view or no?
I don't think it was important in 2000, because nobody voted for Cheney.
They voted for Bush and they got Cheney.
I don't...
I think it may - if Hillary has her way, it's going to be an important issue, because she'll be on the ticket.
I personally don't think that's a smart move on Obama's part, because you don't want to have another Cheney-like vice-president, who really controls everything.
And you're there, just kind of being the puppet, which is the way most people perceive the administration now.
So, I don't know how import - I think it will be important - I'm not sure how important it's going to be though.
Well, don't you think that Cheney sort of energized that office in a way that it had not been energized before.
That's before.
That's an interesting choice of words.
That's one way to put it, right?
A little too much - a little too much energy.
(Soundbite of laughter)
On the Republican side then, who would be good for McCain?
Oh gosh, wasn't there a rumor that Condoleezza Rice was in the running, because you want that contrast.
I think that there's a history of you know, picking a running mate that is not similar to you, or from a different part of the country or something.
And I think, actually I think you know, the Obama-Clinton thing would be - they're too similar, frankly.
I don't think...
Position wise.
Position wise, we - you know.
Of course, different in other ways, but I think, Bob says, it's too much a sense of - it's a Dick Cheney syndrome.
She, I think - she wants to maintain control, which is clear now, and I don't think that would disappear if she were running mate.
I think she was...
Well, if she was a running mate, you would have her as the vice-president, and Bill Clinton as vice-president...
(Soundbite of laughter)
